column4: if you loose your NAS for more than just a NAS you loose some of the important benefits of having a NAS.
depending on what you do with it, you're opening up potential security holes, stability problems, or performance issues.
not saying you shouldn't do it, I don't know what you intend, just that you should keep that tradeoffs in mind.
performance won't be much of an issue.  The planned hardware will be far more is needed for GigE RAID6.  Security...well...it depends, though it wouldn't be a firewall :)

I suppose what it comes down to is just how easy/difficult it is to get disk idle spin-down, timed off/on and wake on lan support.  If it is indeed difficult in Ubuntu or debian, then it would indeed not be a good choice.

timed off/on requires bios support (atleast for the on, a simple script can handle off), wake-on-lan is pretty much the same in all distros if your hardware has good acpi, and there are tools for tweaking disk spin-up/spin-down.
genii/Falstius: Actually no RAID6 in FreeNAS, so it's out of the picture :)
you're planning to do software raid?
Any idea what tools would be used for spin-up/spin-down?
for ide trides, hdparm works.  I can't remember if you just use a switch to get that to work with sata or you use another tool.
Hardware RAID6 is quite pricy, less extendable, and far slower (if more reliable.)
is it slower?  At work they used 3ware cards in raid6 to set transatlantic speed records.
smart raid is typically slower...it's CPU bound, and the CPUs (perhaps except for the top-end ones) certainly can't do what a $70 system CPU can do.
Esepcially RAID6...that's a lot of calculation.
they're good machines, but they simply tend not to be as fast.
Also, for 8-12 total drives, that's a LOT of $700 cards :)
